candidates.paper_1_title: Effects of multi-phase control mechanism on fibroblast dynamics
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Cell size determined by control mechanisms across cell cycle phases (sizer, timer, adder strategies). Division kernel and phase-specific control govern size distribution. Population-density-dependent regulation limits total cell numbers (extrinsic feedback). Cell-size-dependent regulation suppresses size variability (intrinsic feedback). Trade-off between extrinsic and intrinsic control.
candidates.paper_2_title: Coarse-graining and stochastic oscillations in cell-size homeostasis
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Cell size feedback operates through size deviations (difference between absolute size and cell-cycle progression). Feedback from size to growth rate and cycle timing creates coupled dynamics. In linear regime, dynamics reduce to stochastically forced harmonic oscillator. Cell-cycle timing and intrinsic fluctuations jointly shape size control strategy. Mechanistic feedback structure may differ from apparent coarse-grained correlations due to noise integration.

candidates.paper_1_title: Combination therapy for colorectal cancer with anti-PD-L1 and cancer vaccine
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Tumor cells release antigens activating immune T-cells. T-cells attack tumor reducing growth. Tumor evolves PD-L1 expression to suppress T-cell response (escape). Anti-PD-L1 blocks suppression restoring immune attack. Vaccine increases antigen presentation. Combination creates feedback where immune response selects for tumor variants.
candidates.paper_2_title: Combination therapy for colorectal cancer with anti-PD-L1 and cancer vaccine: A multiscale mathematical model of tumor-immune interactions
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Multiple low-dose anti-PD-L1 reduces advanced tumor burden better than single high dose, while cancer vaccines show opposite pattern (maximum dose superior). Cytotoxic T-cell to regulatory T-cell ratio serves as robust pre-treatment biomarker. Different dose-response curves across therapies reflect distinct mechanisms of immune modulation.

candidates.paper_1_title: Learning virulence-transmission relationships using causal inference
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Pathogen virulence (harm to host) causally influences transmission rate (spread to new hosts). Increased virulence may increase transmission initially but reduces host mobility decreasing spread. Trade-off creates optimal virulence level maximizing transmission. Evolutionary dynamics drive virulence toward this optimum. Past virulence predicts future transmission but not vice versa (directional causality).
candidates.paper_2_title: Multi-strain SIS dynamics with coinfection under host population structure
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Multiple pathogen strains circulate and co-infect hosts with different susceptibilities and clearance rates. Host population structure creates differential transmission pathways across classes. Strain interactions through coinfection alter individual transmission dynamics. Class-specific epidemiological traits modulate strain competition and coexistence patterns.

candidates.paper_1_title: Effects of multi-phase control mechanism on fibroblast dynamics
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Cell size determined by control mechanisms across cell cycle phases (sizer, timer, adder strategies). Division kernel and phase-specific control govern size distribution. Population-density-dependent regulation limits total cell numbers (extrinsic feedback). Cell-size-dependent regulation suppresses size variability (intrinsic feedback). Trade-off between extrinsic and intrinsic control.
candidates.paper_2_title: Cell size control in bacteria
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Cell size fluctuates due to noisy growth rates and size-dependent division noise. Size homeostasis mechanisms compensate for fluctuations through size control strategies. Population dynamics alter size distributions compared to single lineages - exponential population growth changes the effective size control measured in constant-volume experiments. Extrinsic growth noise and population structure jointly determine observed size distributions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Collaboration for the Bioeconomy -- Evidence from Innovation Output in Sweden
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Firms collaborate forming innovation network. Central firms access diverse knowledge from multiple partners enhancing innovation output. Peripheral firms limited by fewer connections. Network structure (centrality) determines innovation capacity. Successful innovators attract more partners (preferential attachment) reinforcing centrality advantage.
candidates.paper_2_title: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.

candidates.paper_1_title: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Local monomer depletion from network growth creates negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Higher density causes faster monomer consumption and slower growth. Multiple networks sharing finite monomer pool reach steady states through self-regulation. Under strong competition, coexistence transitions to selection.
candidates.paper_2_title: Thermodynamic Limits of Physical Intelligence
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Local monomer depletion creates negative feedback between network density and growth. Epiplexity (structural information encoding) and empowerment (control capacity) provide recognition vs. control axes for physical intelligence. Landauer-scale closed-cycle benchmarks require explicit boundary-closure and reset assumptions - without charging for external low-entropy resources, information gain and dissipation decouple.

candidates.paper_1_title: Collaboration for the Bioeconomy -- Evidence from Innovation Output in Sweden
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Firms collaborate forming innovation network. Central firms access diverse knowledge from multiple partners enhancing innovation output. Peripheral firms limited by fewer connections. Network structure (centrality) determines innovation capacity. Successful innovators attract more partners (preferential attachment) reinforcing centrality advantage.
candidates.paper_2_title: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Productivity in scientific and technological activities increases with Katz-Bonacich centrality capturing within-activity and cross-activity complementarities. Scientific productivity significantly enhances technological output (asymmetric linkage), but technology does not reciprocally boost science. Science-driven innovation model where collaboration structure influences knowledge creation through network position and cross-domain spillovers.

candidates.paper_1_title: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Plants facilitate neighboring growth through local resource modification. Facilitation competes with resource competition. When precipitation is intermittent, facilitation-competition balance creates spatial vegetation patterns. Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).
candidates.paper_2_title: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.

candidates.paper_1_title: Effects of multi-phase control mechanism on fibroblast dynamics
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Cell size determined by control mechanisms across cell cycle phases (sizer, timer, adder strategies). Division kernel and phase-specific control govern size distribution. Population-density-dependent regulation limits total cell numbers (extrinsic feedback). Cell-size-dependent regulation suppresses size variability (intrinsic feedback). Trade-off between extrinsic and intrinsic control.
candidates.paper_2_title: Cell proliferation maintains cell area polydispersity in the growing fruit fly wing epithelium
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Cell proliferation generates area variability while mechanical forces regulate packing. Cell division creates size asymmetry between daughter cells. Mechanical constraints from neighbors limit expansion. Area polydispersity emerges from balance between proliferation-driven variability and mechanical relaxation. Cell-cell adhesion and cortical tension determine equilibrium distributions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Critical Slowing Down at Bifurcations
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.paper_2_title: Heterogeneity dominates irreversibility in random Markov models
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Markov dynamics combine heterogeneity and asymmetry (broken detailed balance). Heterogeneity parameter controls transition rate variability. Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.

candidates.paper_1_title: From Discrete to Continuous Mixed Populations of Conformists, Nonconformists, and Imitators
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Three behavioral types interact: conformists benefit from choosing common strategies, nonconformists profit from rare strategies, and imitators copy highest earners. Population proportions fluctuate in finite populations but equilibrate as population size increases. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.
candidates.paper_2_title: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.paper_2_title: Chaotic Dynamics in Black Holes
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.

candidates.paper_1_title: Human-AI Cooperation in Public Goods Game
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. Cooperation depends on observed group behavior patterns rather than the identity of participants. These normative mechanisms operate identically regardless of agent type, creating stable cooperation patterns through behavioral feedback.
candidates.paper_2_title: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.

candidates.paper_1_title: Manipulation in Prediction Markets
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Manipulators with high budgets attempt to distort prediction market prices. Informed traders with correct beliefs observe price distortions and increase their opposing bets. Market depth and information heterogeneity determine manipulation effectiveness. When information is dispersed, manipulation can temporarily move prices, but informed arbitrage eventually corrects mispricing. Manipulator budget and trader information quality create a competitive dynamic.
candidates.paper_2_title: Manipulation in Prediction Markets: An Agent-based Modeling Experiment
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: High-budget agents (whales) shift market prices proportionally to their capital share. Distortion duration depends on non-whale learning rates and herding intensity. Fast learners correct distortions quickly; herding amplifies and prolongs whale influence as coordinated followers reinforce biased prices even when informed traders exit.

candidates.paper_1_title: Uncertainty in Island-based Ecosystem Services and Climate Change
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Transmission rate increases with infected density. Recovery rate decreases infection duration. When transmission exceeds recovery (R0>1), epidemic spreads exponentially. Vaccination reduces susceptible population shifting R0 below 1. Spatial heterogeneity creates local pockets where R0 varies.

candidates.paper_2_title: R&D Spillovers and Regional Innovation
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: R&D spillovers from one entity enhance innovation in neighboring entities. Strategic interactions follow Stackelberg dynamics where leaders and followers reach Nash equilibrium. Highly-qualified employment amplifies spillover effects, creating synergies between different types of R&D investment and regional innovation output.

candidates.paper_1_title: Path Integration and Object-Location Binding in Predictive Sequence Model
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Action-conditioned sequential prediction enables path integration and dynamic object-location binding for world modeling. Prediction accuracy improves across sequence through in-context learning. Structured representations with flexible binding emerge to support prediction - new bindings learnable late in sequence, out-of-distribution bindings acquirable through sequential exposure.
candidates.paper_2_title: DreamDojo: Robot World Model from Large-Scale Human Videos
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Continuous latent actions serve as unified proxy actions, enabling interaction knowledge transfer from unlabeled human videos to robot control. World model learns diverse interactions from 44k hours of egocentric video. Post-training on small-scale robot data yields physics understanding and precise action controllability. Generative modeling enables teleoperation, policy evaluation, and planning.

candidates.paper_2_title: Division of labor emerges from heterogeneous thresholds
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Division of labor emerges from heterogeneous response thresholds combined with task-dependent positive feedback. Individuals with low thresholds specialize in corresponding tasks as they activate more frequently and self-reinforce. Threshold distribution determines whether population exhibits generalism or specialized subpopulations. Decentralized coordination through threshold heterogeneity without central control.

candidates.paper_1_title: Free-Rider Problem in Shared Resources
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Shared resource use creates a cooperation dilemma with cleaning costs, contamination risk, and social incentives forming competing pressures. Cleaning cost primarily determines stability of altruistic behavior. The system exhibits multi-stability and hysteresis - small parameter changes can cause abrupt shifts between cooperation and free-riding equilibria.
candidates.paper_2_title: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemics
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

candidates.paper_1_title: DeFi Credit Exposures and Contagion
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.
candidates.paper_2_title: Seed Node Position and Network Damage
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Localized damage initiates at a seed node and propagates to neighbors. The structural position of the seed node (local connectivity and topology) amplifies or dampens damage progression. Cumulative link severing during attack progression depends critically on seed node characteristics rather than average network properties.

candidates.paper_1_title: Mean-Field Price Formation with Network of Relative Performance Concerns
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.
candidates.paper_2_title: Game-Theoretic and Algorithmic Analyses of Multi-Agent Routing under Crossing Costs
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Crossing cost (product of opposing-direction agent counts) quantifies conflict risk in asynchronous multi-agent routing. Pure Nash equilibria exist when agents minimize individual crossing exposure. Equilibrium emergence dynamics depend on network structure - general case is PLS-complete, but polynomial-time solvable under mild structural conditions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Habitat Heterogeneity and Metacommunity Dynamics
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Spatial structure and dispersal networks jointly determine species persistence. Heterogeneous habitats support stable coexistence only above a critical heterogeneity threshold. Homogeneous environments allow coexistence only in a fine-tuned marginal state, creating instability. Network topology encodes dispersal effectiveness through an effective kernel.
candidates.paper_2_title: Cross-feeding yields high-dimensional chaos and coexistence of species
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.

candidates.paper_1_title: Semantic Memory to Collective Creativity
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Individual semantic network topology determines ideational breadth. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower initial overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy, forming feedback between individual cognitive structure and collective outcomes.
candidates.paper_2_title: Emergent structures in coupled opinion and network dynamics
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Individuals' opinions and network edge weights coevolve through coupled dynamics. Interaction strength depends on opinion distance. Similar opinions strengthen network connections. Connection strength amplifies opinion influence. This creates feedback between opinion convergence and network structure formation. Interaction function form determines emergent structures and stability.

candidates.paper_1_title: Human-AI Cooperation in Public Goods Game
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. candidates.paper_2_title: A brief review of evolutionary game dynamics in the reinforcement learning paradigm
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Reinforcement learning paradigm differs from imitation learning by enabling introspective strategy refinement through trial-and-error rather than copying successful neighbors. Individuals learn from environmental feedback and adapt based on personal experience. This resolves discrepancies between theoretical predictions and behavioral experiments in cooperation, trust, and fairness.

candidates.paper_1_title: Optimal Harvesting in Stream Networks: Maximizing Biomass and Yield
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Resource stock accumulates from production flow. Exploitation (flow out) versus conservation (stock maintenance) tradeoff. Maximum sustainable yield occurs at intermediate stock level. Over-exploitation depletes stock below replenishment threshold causing collapse.
candidates.paper_2_title: Who sets the range? Funding mechanics and context in crypto markets
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Funding rates in perpetual futures impose economic costs on leveraged positions. High funding creates pressure to reduce directional exposure. Capital rebalancing occurs when funding costs exceed expected returns. Funding mechanisms act as negative feedback regulating trader behavior - extreme positions become economically unsustainable, creating mean-reverting pressure that defines trading ranges.

Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.

candidates.paper_1_title: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Plants facilitate neighboring growth through local resource modification. Facilitation competes with resource competition. When precipitation is intermittent, facilitation-competition balance creates spatial vegetation patterns. Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).
candidates.paper_2_title: Growth Models Under Catastrophes
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Catastrophic events trigger population dispersal strategies. Dispersion affects survival probability and extinction time. Spatial constraints modulate the effectiveness of dispersal - unconstrained dispersion improves survival while spatial limits reduce the benefit, creating a trade-off between mobility and stability.

candidates.paper_1_title: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.
candidates.paper_2_title: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemics
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

candidates.paper_1_title: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.
candidates.paper_2_title: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.

candidates.paper_1_title: Chaotic Dynamics in Black Holes
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.
candidates.paper_2_title: Heterogeneity dominates irreversibility in random Markov models
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Markov dynamics combine heterogeneity and asymmetry (broken detailed balance). Heterogeneity parameter controls transition rate variability. Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.

candidates.paper_1_title: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemics

Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.
candidates.paper_2_title: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Spatially-Structured Kinship Networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Threshold-based resource redistribution creates feedback between network structure and resource allocation ability. Agents below threshold solicit help; helpers contribute fractionally based on relatedness. Higher local density and relational closeness emerge as redistribution-dependent survival creates centralized clusters through cooperative resource sharing.

candidates.paper_1_title: Hypergraph Neural Networks for Multi-Agent Pathfinding
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Hypergraph attention captures group (beyond pairwise) coordination dynamics in multi-agent pathfinding. Standard GNNs limited to pairwise message passing suffer attention dilution in dense environments where group coordination is critical. Attentional mechanisms over directed hypergraphs explicitly model higher-order interactions, mitigating representational bottleneck and enabling complex coordination where pairwise methods fail.
candidates.paper_2_title: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

candidates.paper_1_title: Seed Node Position and Network Damage
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Localized damage initiates at a seed node and propagates to neighbors. The structural position of the seed node (local connectivity and topology) amplifies or dampens damage progression. Cumulative link severing during attack progression depends critically on seed node characteristics rather than average network properties.
candidates.paper_2_title: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.

candidates.paper_1_title: Mean-Field Price Formation with Network of Relative Performance Concerns
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.
candidates.paper_2_title: Manipulation in Prediction Markets: An Agent-based Modeling Experiment
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: High-budget agents (whales) shift market prices proportionally to their capital share. Distortion duration depends on non-whale learning rates and herding intensity. Fast learners correct distortions quickly; herding amplifies and prolongs whale influence as coordinated followers reinforce biased prices even when informed traders exit.

candidates.paper_1_title: Uncertainty in Island-based Ecosystem Services and Climate Change
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Transmission rate increases with infected density. Recovery rate decreases infection duration. When transmission exceeds recovery (R0>1), epidemic spreads exponentially. Vaccination reduces susceptible population shifting R0 below 1. Spatial heterogeneity creates local pockets where R0 varies.
candidates.paper_2_title: Fish Migration and Feller Condition
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: The ratio between diffusion and drift (Feller condition) determines qualitative migration properties. High diffusion relative to drift creates randomized, intermittent movement patterns. Low ratio produces more deterministic, continuous movement. This ratio acts as a control parameter governing timescale-dependent behavioral transitions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Group Selection and AI Substitution
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: AI use reduces cultural variance in populations. Under individual selection, agents relying heavily on AI (substitutes) outcompete those using AI as complement, despite reducing variance more. Group selection can favor agents that maintain variance through complementary AI use when group boundaries are strong, creating selection-level competition.
candidates.paper_2_title: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Learning virulence-transmission relationships using causal inference
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Pathogen virulence (harm to host) causally influences transmission rate (spread to new hosts). Increased virulence may increase transmission initially but reduces host mobility decreasing spread. Trade-off creates optimal virulence level maximizing transmission. Evolutionary dynamics drive virulence toward this optimum. Past virulence predicts future transmission but not vice versa (directional causality).

candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Variable group sizes in majority-rule dynamics create heterogeneous influence through effective majority leverage. Rare large-group events can realign substantial population fractions. Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.
candidates.paper_2_title: Division of labor emerges from heterogeneous thresholds
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Division of labor emerges from heterogeneous response thresholds combined with task-dependent positive feedback. Individuals with low thresholds specialize in corresponding tasks as they activate more frequently and self-reinforce. Threshold distribution determines whether population exhibits generalism or specialized subpopulations. Decentralized coordination through threshold heterogeneity without central control.

candidates.paper_1_title: Multi-strain SIS dynamics with coinfection under host population structure
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Multiple pathogen strains circulate and co-infect hosts with different susceptibilities and clearance rates. Host population structure creates differential transmission pathways across classes. Strain interactions through coinfection alter individual transmission dynamics. Class-specific epidemiological traits modulate strain competition and coexistence patterns.

Nutrient supply and conversion efficiency determine phase boundary. Spreading rate distinguishes dominant limitation type.

candidates.paper_2_title: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.

candidates.paper_1_title: From Discrete to Continuous Mixed Populations of Conformists, Nonconformists, and Imitators
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Three behavioral types interact: conformists benefit from choosing common strategies, nonconformists profit from rare strategies, and imitators copy highest earners. Population proportions fluctuate in finite populations but equilibrate as population size increases. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.
candidates.paper_2_title: Mathematical Modeling of Common-Pool Resources
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.

candidates.paper_1_title: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Kinship Networks
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: When agents fall below a resource threshold, they solicit resources from connected neighbors based on relatedness. Redistribution creates feedback between kinship network structure and reproduction ability. This enables population survival at lower resource densities but increases network heterogeneity and local centralization.
candidates.paper_2_title: Mean-Field Price Formation with Network of Relative Performance Concerns

Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.

candidates.paper_1_title: Metastability and ripening of multi-component liquid mixtures
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Multi-component mixtures undergo phase separation through unstable coexistence. Droplets grow via Ostwald ripening with characteristic scaling (radius ~ t^1/3, number ~ n^-2/3). Glass-like relaxation emerges from disordered interactions among components, creating long-lived metastable states. Different wetting angles characterize metastable configurations. Relaxation delay arises from kinetic barriers between metastable states.
candidates.paper_2_title: Distributed delay stabilizes bistable genetic networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Protein production involves delayed multi-step process (transcription, translation, folding, oligomerization). Delay is distributed (noisy) due to stochastic process durations. Increasing delay noise dramatically stabilizes metastable states in bistable circuits. Mean residence times in metastable states increase with delay distribution width. Distributed delay prevents unwanted switching caused by small fluctuations while allowing controlled transitions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Thermalization in Discrete Systems
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Local ergodicity in subsystems, rather than global ergodicity, enables thermalization. Subsystem dynamics appear pseudorandom due to local interactions. Statistical properties of observables emerge from this effective local randomization without requiring the entire system to be ergodic.
candidates.paper_2_title: Noisy nonlocal aggregation model with gradient flow structures
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Stochastic perturbations in nonlocal aggregation systems create gradient-flow structure in Wasserstein space. Stable energy minimizers emerge from interplay between potential-driven interactions and environmental variability.

candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Temporal niche differentiation through phenotypic plasticity in circadian rhythms enables species coexistence. Coexistence emerges when plastic responses generate sufficient temporal separation in resource use patterns.

candidates.paper_1_title: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns

candidates.paper_2_title: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback

candidates.paper_2_title: Emergent structures in coupled opinion and network dynamics

candidates.paper_1_title: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.
candidates.paper_2_title: From semantic memory to collective creativity: A generative cognitive foundation for social creativity models
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Semantic network topology determines ideational breadth - low modularity yields broader exploration. candidates.paper_1_title: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Network growth locally depletes monomers creating negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Local depletion couples network growth rates through shared resource. Under weak competition, networks coexist at steady state. Under strong competition, selection replaces coexistence - fastest-growing network excludes others. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.
candidates.paper_2_title: Thermodynamic Limits of Physical Intelligence
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Local monomer depletion creates negative feedback between network density and growth. Epiplexity (structural information encoding) and empowerment (control capacity) provide recognition vs. control axes for physical intelligence. Evolutionary dynamics drive virulence toward this optimum. Past virulence predicts future transmission but not vice versa (directional causality).
candidates.paper_2_title: Growth Models Under Catastrophes
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Catastrophic events trigger population dispersal strategies. Dispersion affects survival probability and extinction time. Spatial constraints modulate the effectiveness of dispersal - unconstrained dispersion improves survival while spatial limits reduce the benefit, creating a trade-off between mobility and stability.

Fast learners correct distortions quickly; herding amplifies and prolongs whale influence as coordinated followers reinforce biased prices even when informed traders exit.

candidates.paper_1_title: Who sets the range? Funding mechanics and context in crypto markets
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Funding rates in perpetual futures impose economic costs on leveraged positions. High funding creates pressure to reduce directional exposure. Capital rebalancing occurs when funding costs exceed expected returns. Funding mechanisms act as negative feedback regulating trader behavior - extreme positions become economically unsustainable, creating mean-reverting pressure that defines trading ranges.

candidates.paper_1_title: Imperfect molecular detection renormalizes apparent kinetic rates
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Imperfect molecular detection in single-cell measurements introduces technical noise obscuring true dynamics. Binomial capture models describe detection inefficiency. Under high transcription factor abundance or timescale separation, capture effects renormalize kinetic rates. Apparent mean burst size appears reduced while binding reactions appear faster. Technical noise reshapes observed statistics without changing underlying mechanism - creates measurement-induced effective parameters.
candidates.paper_2_title: Locally Gentle State Certification for High Dimensional Quantum Systems
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Measurement gentleness constraint (α-bounded state perturbation) imposes information extraction penalty. Sample complexity scales as d/α² - the trade-off between disturbance and information parallels privacy mechanisms. Gentler measurements require more samples but preserve quantum state for reuse, creating fundamental efficiency-preservation trade-off.

candidates.paper_1_title: Critical Slowing Down at Bifurcations

candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Pathogen virulence (harm to host) causally influences transmission rate (spread to new hosts). candidates.paper_1_title: Uncertainty in Island-based Ecosystem Services and Climate Change

Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

candidates.paper_2_title: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Standard GNNs limited to pairwise message passing suffer attention dilution in dense environments where group coordination is critical. Attentional mechanisms over directed hypergraphs explicitly model higher-order interactions, mitigating representational bottleneck and enabling complex coordination where pairwise methods fail.

candidates.paper_1_title: Chaotic Dynamics in Black Holes
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.
candidates.paper_2_title: Nonlinear wave mixing via collective oscillations
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Collective oscillations in many-body systems mediate nonlinear wave mixing without requiring strong single-particle nonlinearity. Coherent many-body response creates effective nonlinearity through collective mode coupling. Weak individual interactions amplified by collective dynamics generate strong wave mixing. Effective interaction strength scales with system size or coupling density.

candidates.paper_1_title: Learning virulence-transmission relationships using causal inference
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Pathogen virulence (harm to host) causally influences transmission rate (spread to new hosts). Increased virulence may increase transmission initially but reduces host mobility decreasing spread. Trade-off creates optimal virulence level maximizing transmission. Evolutionary dynamics drive virulence toward this optimum. Past virulence predicts future transmission but not vice versa (directional causality).
candidates.paper_2_title: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Noisy nonlocal aggregation model with gradient flow structures
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Stochastic perturbations in nonlocal aggregation systems create gradient-flow structure in Wasserstein space. Noise regulates density and prevents singular concentration through equilibrium states from constrained energy minimization. Stable energy minimizers emerge from interplay between potential-driven interactions and environmental variability.
candidates.paper_2_title: Microbiome association diversity reflects proximity to the edge of instability
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Microbial communities operate near edge of instability - transition from stable fixed-point to chaos controlled by network sparsity and interaction heterogeneity. Effective stability parameter inferred from pairwise covariance distribution width. Healthy gut microbiomes cluster near instability edge with broader associations; dysbiosis shifts toward stable regimes with narrower association distributions.

candidates.paper_1_title: Thermalization in Discrete Systems
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Local ergodicity in subsystems, rather than global ergodicity, enables thermalization. Subsystem dynamics appear pseudorandom due to local interactions. Statistical properties of observables emerge from this effective local randomization without requiring the entire system to be ergodic.

candidates.paper_1_title: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Network growth locally depletes monomers creating negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Local depletion couples network growth rates through shared resource. Under weak competition, networks coexist at steady state. Under strong competition, selection replaces coexistence - fastest-growing network excludes others. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.
candidates.paper_2_title: Individual-Level Strategy Diversity in Differential Evolution
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Assigning mutation and crossover strategies independently to each individual at initialization and keeping them fixed creates persistent behavioral heterogeneity. Static individual-level diversity (no adaptation) cultivates search effectiveness especially with large populations. Communication-free construction enables intrinsic concurrency and efficient parallel execution.

candidates.paper_1_title: Intelligent Control of Transportation Flow in Physarum Networks
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Physarum network morphology responds to environmental stimuli by expanding or retracting tubes. Cytoplasmic flow bidirectionally transports nutrients through the network. Flow patterns optimize based on nutrient source locations. Network adapts topology through tube reinforcement when flow is high and tube degradation when flow is low. This creates an intelligent search for optimal transport paths through flow-structure feedback.
candidates.paper_2_title: Thermodynamic Constraints Drive Hierarchical Preemption in Cellular Decision-Making
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Under stress, cells face rapid pathway selection with ATP scarcity. Continuous ATP regeneration rescues sporulation despite 99.7% ATP depletion. GTP accumulates as energy buffer while ATP regenerates preventing complete depletion. Stochastic regulatory transitions couple to continuous metabolic flux. Energy efficiency emerges from interplay between discrete regulatory logic and continuous thermodynamic constraints. System robustness through dynamic energy management enables 16-fold efficiency gain under stress.

candidates.paper_1_title: Seed Node Position and Network Damage
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Localized damage initiates at a seed node and propagates to neighbors. The structural position of the seed node (local connectivity and topology) amplifies or dampens damage progression. Cumulative link severing during attack progression depends critically on seed node characteristics rather than average network properties.
candidates.paper_2_title: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Local monomer depletion from network growth creates negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Higher density causes faster monomer consumption and slower growth. Multiple networks sharing finite monomer pool reach steady states through self-regulation. Under strong competition, coexistence transitions to selection.

candidates.paper_1_title: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries

Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.paper_2_title: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.

candidates.paper_2_title: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Network growth locally depletes monomers creating negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Local depletion couples network growth rates through shared resource. Under weak competition, networks coexist at steady state. Under strong competition, selection replaces coexistence - fastest-growing network excludes others. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.

candidates.paper_1_title: Chaotic Dynamics in Black Holes
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.
candidates.paper_2_title: Microbiome association diversity reflects proximity to the edge of instability
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Microbial communities operate near edge of instability - transition from stable fixed-point to chaos controlled by network sparsity and interaction heterogeneity. Effective stability parameter inferred from pairwise covariance distribution width. Healthy gut microbiomes cluster near instability edge with broader associations; dysbiosis shifts toward stable regimes with narrower association distributions.

candidates.paper_1_title: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.
candidates.paper_2_title: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.

candidates.paper_1_title: Human-AI Cooperation in Public Goods Game
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. Cooperation depends on observed group behavior patterns rather than the identity of participants. These normative mechanisms operate identically regardless of agent type, creating stable cooperation patterns through behavioral feedback.
candidates.paper_2_title: Temporal niche differentiation through plasticity enables coexistence
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Temporal niche differentiation through phenotypic plasticity in circadian rhythms enables species coexistence. Phase-locking of coupled oscillators creates temporal resource partitioning. Plasticity allows dynamic adjustment of activity timing based on competitor presence. Coexistence emerges when plastic responses generate sufficient temporal separation in resource use patterns.

candidates.paper_1_title: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Kinship Networks
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: When agents fall below a resource threshold, they solicit resources from connected neighbors based on relatedness. Redistribution creates feedback between kinship network structure and reproduction ability. This enables population survival at lower resource densities but increases network heterogeneity and local centralization.
candidates.paper_2_title: Manipulation in Prediction Markets: An Agent-based Modeling Experiment
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: High-budget agents (whales) shift market prices proportionally to their capital share. Distortion duration depends on non-whale learning rates and herding intensity. Fast learners correct distortions quickly; herding amplifies and prolongs whale influence as coordinated followers reinforce biased prices even when informed traders exit.

candidates.paper_1_title: DeFi Credit Exposures and Contagion
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.
candidates.paper_2_title: Intelligent Control of Transportation Flow in Physarum Networks
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Physarum network morphology responds to environmental stimuli by expanding or retracting tubes. Cytoplasmic flow bidirectionally transports nutrients through the network. Flow patterns optimize based on nutrient source locations. Network adapts topology through tube reinforcement when flow is high and tube degradation when flow is low. This creates an intelligent search for optimal transport paths through flow-structure feedback.

candidates.paper_1_title: Cell size control in bacteria
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Cell size fluctuates due to noisy growth rates and size-dependent division noise. Size homeostasis mechanisms compensate for fluctuations through size control strategies. Population dynamics alter size distributions compared to single lineages - exponential population growth changes the effective size control measured in constant-volume experiments. Extrinsic growth noise and population structure jointly determine observed size distributions.
candidates.paper_2_title: Noisy nonlocal aggregation model with gradient flow structures
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Stochastic perturbations in nonlocal aggregation systems create gradient-flow structure in Wasserstein space. Noise regulates density and prevents singular concentration through equilibrium states from constrained energy minimization. Stable energy minimizers emerge from interplay between potential-driven interactions and environmental variability.

candidates.paper_1_title: Cross-feeding yields high-dimensional chaos and coexistence of species
candidates.paper_1_mechanism: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.
candidates.paper_2_title: Mathematical Modeling of Common-Pool Resources
candidates.paper_2_mechanism: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.
